verses.text: Joash was seven years old when he became king, and he reigned forty years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Zibiah from Beersheba.
verses.comment: Joash’s young age highlights divine providence over the Davidic line, which foreshadows God’s preservation of His people throughout salvation history. The forty-year reign echoes periods of testing and fulfillment (see Ex. 16:35; 1 Kings 2:10).

verses.text: Joash did what was right in the eyes of the Lord all the days of Jehoiada the priest.
verses.comment: Joash’s faithfulness is linked to Jehoiada’s guidance, hinting at the importance of spiritual authority and tradition for right worship and life (cf. 1 Chron. 15:27).

verses.text: Jehoiada arranged two wives for him, and he had sons and daughters.
verses.comment: The priest’s role in arranging the king’s family structure underlines harmony between spiritual and royal offices for establishing God’s covenant promises.

verses.text: After this, Joash set his heart on restoring the house of the Lord.
verses.comment: Joash’s desire to restore the temple reveals a zeal for the Lord’s presence and proper worship—essential for continuity of faith.

verses.text: He gathered the priests and Levites and said, 'Go to the cities of Judah and collect money from all Israel to repair the house of your God every year. See that you act quickly.' But the Levites did not act immediately.
verses.comment: Joash’s directive emphasizes communal responsibility for sacred spaces, echoing a perennial call to support the faith’s visible expressions.

verses.text: So the king summoned Jehoiada the chief and said to him, 'Why have you not required the Levites to bring in from Judah and Jerusalem the levy set by Moses, the servant of the Lord, and the congregation of Israel for the tent of the testimony?'
verses.comment: Reference to Moses reinforces the continuity and authority of tradition. The “tent of testimony” connects temple worship to the original tabernacle, showing the unchanging core of faith from generation to generation.

verses.text: For the sons of Athaliah, that wicked woman, had broken into the house of God and had even used all the sacred things of the house of the Lord for the Baals.
verses.comment: The desecration by Athaliah’s sons demonstrates the gravity of idolatry and highlights the sacredness of God’s house—a perpetual truth for all Christian worship.

verses.text: At the king’s command, they made a chest and set it outside the gate of the house of the Lord.
verses.comment: Setting up a central place for offerings lays precedence for visible acts of giving to God’s work, a tradition enduring into Christian practice (cf. 2 Cor. 9:7).

verses.text: And they made a proclamation throughout Judah and Jerusalem, asking people to bring to the Lord what Moses, the servant of God, had established for Israel in the wilderness.
verses.comment: Connecting current worship and giving to Moses forms a bridge to the foundational covenant, suggesting ongoing relevance of traditions instituted by God’s servants.

verses.text: All the leaders and all the people rejoiced and brought their contributions and cast them into the chest until it was full.
verses.comment: See how joy and generosity mark true worship; this mirrors the New Testament call to cheerful giving (2 Cor. 9:7).

verses.text: Whenever the chest was brought by the Levites to the king’s officers, and when they saw there was much money, the king’s scribe and the chief priest’s officer would empty the chest and restore it to its place. They did this day after day and collected a large amount of money.
verses.comment: Daily stewardship manifests trustworthiness in handling God’s resources—pointing to the value of organized, accountable church leadership.

verses.text: The king and Jehoiada gave the money to those who did the work of restoring the house of the Lord, and they hired masons and carpenters to repair the house, and also those who worked in iron and bronze to restore the house of the Lord.
verses.comment: The delegation to skilled workers reaffirms that maintaining houses of worship is a noble task worthy of skilled hands, recalling the labor on the tabernacle (Ex. 36:1).

verses.text: So the workers labored, and the repairs progressed under their hands; they restored the house of God to its proper condition and strengthened it.
verses.comment: Restoration typically refers both to the physical and the spiritual renewal—foreshadowing how God's house is continually called to be renewed and strengthened by His people.

verses.text: When they had finished, they brought the rest of the money before the king and Jehoiada, and with it they made utensils for the house of the Lord, utensils for serving and offering, ladles and vessels of gold and silver. They offered burnt offerings in the house of the Lord continually, all the days of Jehoiada.
verses.comment: The completion of utensils for worship recalls God's command in Exodus and the ongoing sacrifices represents spiritual fidelity, exemplifying devotion through visible ritual.

verses.text: But Jehoiada grew old and died; he was one hundred and thirty years old at his death.
verses.comment: The longevity and godly influence of Jehoiada serve as a testament to a life lived in service to God’s people, reminiscent of the elders in the patriarchal era.

verses.text: He was buried in the city of David among the kings, because he had done good in Israel for God and His house.
verses.comment: Burial among kings is a profound recognition that spiritual leadership can surpass even royal status—hinting at the honor due to God’s servants throughout history.

verses.text: After Jehoiada’s death, the officials of Judah came and bowed down before the king; the king listened to them.
verses.comment: Joash’s shift from priestly advice to listening to officials foreshadows the danger of departing from apostolic authority and tradition.

verses.text: They abandoned the house of the Lord, the God of their ancestors, and served the Asherim and the idols. Wrath came upon Judah and Jerusalem because of this guilt.
verses.comment: Apostasy brings judgment, warning against forsaking God’s appointed means of grace and true worship for false substitutes.

verses.text: Yet God sent prophets among them to bring them back to the Lord. These testified against them, but they would not listen.
verses.comment: God’s patient outreach through prophets shows His desire for repentance and restoration—a theme fulfilled in Jesus, the ultimate Prophet.

verses.text: Then the Spirit of God came upon Zechariah, son of Jehoiada the priest. He stood before the people and said, 'This is what God says: Why do you transgress the commandments of the Lord, so that you cannot prosper? Because you have forsaken the Lord, He has also forsaken you.'
verses.comment: The Spirit’s empowerment and Zechariah’s prophetic courage prefigure Christ’s prophetic office and His warnings to turn back to God.

verses.text: But they conspired against him, and by command of the king, they stoned him in the court of the house of the Lord.
verses.comment: Zechariah’s martyrdom in the temple is later referenced by Jesus (see Matt. 23:35), foreshadowing Christ’s own suffering and the reality of persecution awaiting God’s faithful witnesses.

verses.text: Thus King Joash did not remember the kindness which Zechariah’s father Jehoiada had shown him, but killed his son. As Zechariah was dying, he said, 'May the Lord see and avenge!'
verses.comment: The prayer for justice underlines divine retribution as a comfort for the oppressed, and echoes imprecatory Psalms and Christ’s own calls for justice (Luke 18:7).

verses.text: At the turn of the year, the army of Aram came up against Joash. They invaded Judah and Jerusalem, destroyed all the leaders among the people, and sent all their spoil to the king of Damascus.
verses.comment: Foreign invasion as divine judgment occurs repeatedly in Scripture, warning of consequences when leaders forsake God’s law.

verses.text: Though the Aramean army came with only a few men, the Lord delivered a very great army into their hand, because Judah had forsaken the Lord, the God of their ancestors. So they executed judgment on Joash.
verses.comment: God’s sovereign control over victory and defeat teaches that spiritual allegiance has tangible consequences in history. The small Aramean force’s success recalls God’s power to judge despite appearances.

verses.text: When they withdrew from him—for they left him severely wounded—his servants conspired against him because of the blood of the son of Jehoiada the priest, and killed him on his bed. He died, and they buried him in the city of David, but not in the tombs of the kings.
verses.comment: Joash’s disgraceful burial contrasts Jehoiada’s honor, affirming that faithless rulers forfeit spiritual legacy.

verses.text: The conspirators were Zabad son of Shimeath, an Ammonite woman, and Jehozabad son of Shimrith, a Moabite woman.
verses.comment: Foreign lineage of the conspirators may symbolize the corruption and division that arises when covenant loyalty is abandoned.

verses.text: The accounts of his sons, the many prophecies against him, and the restoration of the house of God are written in the stories of the Kings. Amaziah, his son, became king in his place.
verses.comment: Reference to written records highlights respect for history and tradition, and the passing of the kingship denotes the enduring leadership structure in God's chosen people, anticipating its fulfillment in Christ the true King and through apostolic succession.
